slump.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to fall or lean against something because you are not strong enough to stand
slump.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Carol slumped back in her chair, defeated.
Ben staggered and slumped onto the floor.
slump.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to suddenly go down in price, value, or number
slump.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The currency slumped to a record low.
slump.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if your shoulders or head slump or are slumped, they bend forward because you are unhappy, tired, or unconscious
slump.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Her shoulders slumped and her eyes filled with tears.
slump.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a sudden decrease in prices, sales, profits etc
slump.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a period when there is a reduction in business and many people lose their jobs
slump.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The war was followed by an economic slump.
slump.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a period when a player or team does not play well
slump.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The Dodgers have been in a slump for the last three weeks.
slump.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a sudden fall in the price, value, or number of something
slump.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: There has been a slump in sales this month.
slump.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: a period of time when there is a big reduction in economic activity, forcing many companies to close and many people to lose their jobs
slump.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Savings were already extremely low at the beginning of the current slump.
